forum1.title: Best areas to live in Lisbon
forum1.content: I'm moving to Lisbon next month and would like recommendations on the best areas to live that are close to universities.
forum1.author: João Silva
messages: I'm moving to Lisbon next month and would like recommendations on the best areas to live that are close to universities.
Try Alvalade or Campo Pequeno. These areas are close to major universities and have good public transportation. They're also quite safe and have many student-friendly cafes.
Thank you for the suggestions! Do you know what the average rent is in those areas for a one-bedroom apartment?

forum2.title: Rental prices in Porto
forum2.content: Has anyone noticed the increasing rental prices in Porto? Is it still affordable for students?
forum2.author: Maria Santos
messages: Has anyone noticed the increasing rental prices in Porto? Is it still affordable for students?

Yes! It's becoming harder to find affordable places near the center. Prices have gone up about 25% in the last year alone. Most students are now looking at areas like Paranhos or sharing with multiple roommates.

forum3.title: Tenant rights in Portugal
forum3.content: I would like to know more about tenant rights in Portugal. What are the regulations regarding security deposits?
forum3.author: Ana Pereira
messages: I would like to know more about tenant rights in Portugal. What are the regulations regarding security deposits?

Typically, landlords can request up to two months' rent as a deposit. By law, this deposit must be returned within 30 days of the end of your lease, provided there are no damages beyond normal wear and tear.

forum4.title: Problems with noisy neighbors
forum4.content: How to deal with noisy neighbors in an apartment building? I've tried talking to them but it didn't help.
forum4.author: Pedro Costa
messages: How to deal with noisy neighbors in an apartment building? I've tried talking to them but it didn't help. They keep playing loud music until 3 AM on weekdays.

Try contacting the building management or writing a formal complaint. If that doesn't work, you can file a noise complaint with the local police. Document incidents with recordings and timestamps to support your case.

forum5.title: Renovation permits for landlords
forum5.content: What permits do I need to renovate my rental property? The process seems complicated.
forum5.author: Carlos Mendes
messages: What permits do I need to renovate my rental property? The process seems complicated. I'm planning to update the kitchen and bathroom.

I can help you with that. I have experience in renovations. For kitchen and bathroom updates, you'll need a 'comunicação prévia' from your local Câmara Municipal. Make sure to hire licensed contractors who can help with the paperwork.

My grandma is a landlord and she said that you need to apply for a renovation permit at the local municipality office. It's important to have all the necessary documents ready, including property deeds and detailed renovation plans.
